verses.text: You shall not make idols for yourselves or carve an image or set up a pillar for yourselves, nor shall you place any sculptured stone in your land to bow down to it; for I am the LORD your God.
verses.comment: Preserved the direct prohibition against idols and images, as in Hebrew.

verses.text: You shall keep my Sabbaths and revere my sanctuary; I am the LORD.
verses.comment: Echoes the earlier command concerning Sabbaths and the place of worship.

verses.text: If you walk in my statutes and keep my commandments and do them,
verses.comment: Condition for the blessings that follow.

verses.text: then I will give you rain in its season, and the land shall yield its produce, and the trees of the field shall bear their fruit.
verses.comment: Rain and harvest are direct rewards for obedience.

verses.text: Your threshing will last until the grape harvest, and the grape harvest will last until sowing time; you will eat your bread to the full and live securely in your land.
verses.comment: "Threshing will last until grape harvest" preserves the agricultural metaphors.

verses.text: I will give peace in the land, and you shall lie down, and none will make you afraid. I will remove harmful beasts from the land, and the sword shall not pass through your land.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of "the sword will not pass through your land."

verses.text: You will pursue your enemies, and they shall fall before you by the sword.
verses.comment: Kept the image of conquest and defeat.

verses.text: Five of you shall chase a hundred, and a hundred of you shall chase ten thousand, and your enemies shall fall before you by the sword.
verses.comment: Numbers preserved as in original.

verses.text: I will turn toward you and make you fruitful and multiply you, and I will confirm my covenant with you.
verses.comment: "Turn toward you" as literal to the Hebrew "set my face toward you."

verses.text: You shall eat old store long kept, and you shall have to clear out the old to make room for the new.
verses.comment: The abundance is such that old harvests are still around when new ones come.

verses.text: I will set my dwelling among you, and my soul shall not abhor you.
verses.comment: Kept "my dwelling" as a reference to God’s tabernacling.

verses.text: I will walk among you and will be your God, and you shall be my people.
verses.comment: Echoes covenant formula, very literal.

verses.text: I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt so that you would no longer be slaves. I broke the bars of your yoke and made you walk upright.
verses.comment: Bars of the yoke—preserves metaphor of slavery broken.

verses.text: But if you will not listen to me and will not do all these commandments,
verses.comment: Introduction of disobedience curses.

verses.text: if you despise my statutes, and if your soul abhors my rules, so that you do not do all my commandments, but break my covenant,
verses.comment: "Abhor" retains the strong word for rejection.

verses.text: then I will do this to you: I will visit you with panic, wasting disease and fever that consume the eyes and make the soul pine away. You shall sow your seed in vain, for your enemies shall eat it.
verses.comment: Disease terms and agricultural curses kept literal.

verses.text: I will set my face against you, and you shall be struck down before your enemies. Those who hate you shall rule over you, and you shall flee even when no one pursues you.
verses.comment: "Set my face against you" matches Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: And if after all this you will not listen to me, then I will discipline you again seven times for your sins.
verses.comment: "Seven times" kept literal; denotes completeness.

verses.text: And I will break the pride of your power, and I will make your skies like iron and your land like bronze.
verses.comment: "Skies like iron" is a literal Hebrew simile.

verses.text: Your strength shall be spent in vain, for your land shall not yield its produce, and the trees of the land shall not yield their fruit.
verses.comment: Agricultural failure is a common biblical curse.

verses.text: If you walk contrary to me and will not listen to me, I will bring more plagues upon you, seven times as many as your sins.
verses.comment: Phrase "contrary to me" keeps the Hebrew meaning.

verses.text: And I will send wild animals among you, which will rob you of your children and destroy your livestock and make you few in number, so that your roads shall be deserted.
verses.comment: Wild animals as divine judgment is kept direct.

verses.text: And if by these things you are not corrected by me, but walk contrary to me,
verses.comment: Phrase "walk contrary to me" stays literal to Hebrew.

verses.text: then I also will walk contrary to you, and I myself will strike you seven times for your sins.
verses.comment: Reciprocal use of "walk contrary" preserved.

verses.text: And I will bring a sword upon you, that will execute vengeance for the covenant. When you gather within your cities, I will send pestilence among you, and you shall be delivered into the hand of the enemy.
verses.comment: Vengeance for the covenant kept as literal concept.

verses.text: When I break your supply of bread, ten women shall bake your bread in one oven, and they shall return your bread by weight; and you shall eat and not be satisfied.
verses.comment: "By weight" reflects severe scarcity.

verses.text: And if in spite of this you will not listen to me, but walk contrary to me,
verses.comment: Repeated formula of warning.

verses.text: then I will walk contrary to you in fury, and I myself will discipline you seven times for your sins.
verses.comment: Adds "in fury" to intensify divine judgment.

verses.text: You shall eat the flesh of your sons, and you shall eat the flesh of your daughters.
verses.comment: Grim consequence of siege and famine.

verses.text: I will destroy your high places and cut down your incense altars and heap your dead on the lifeless forms of your idols, and my soul will abhor you.
verses.comment: High places and incense altars relate to idolatrous worship.

verses.text: And I will make your cities a waste and will make your sanctuaries desolate, and I will not smell the pleasing aroma of your offerings.
verses.comment: "Smell the pleasing aroma" is perhaps more idiomatic today but kept literal.

verses.text: And I myself will devastate the land, so that your enemies who settle in it will be appalled at it.
verses.comment: Desolation will shock other nations.

verses.text: And I will scatter you among the nations, and I will unsheath the sword after you, and your land shall be a desolation and your cities a waste.
verses.comment: Exile language; "unsheath the sword" kept literal.

verses.text: Then the land shall enjoy its Sabbaths as long as it lies desolate while you are in your enemies' land; then the land shall rest and enjoy its Sabbaths.
verses.comment: Links land’s rest with Israel’s exile.

verses.text: As long as it lies desolate, it shall have the rest that it did not have in your Sabbaths when you lived in it.
verses.comment: Rest for the land is a major theme. Literal rendering.

verses.text: And as for those who are left among you, I will send fear into their hearts in the lands of their enemies, and the sound of a driven leaf shall put them to flight, and they shall flee as one flees from a sword, and they shall fall though no one pursues them.
verses.comment: "Driven leaf" idiom kept literal.

verses.text: They shall stumble over one another as if fleeing from the sword, though no one pursues, and you shall have no power to stand before your enemies.
verses.comment: "Stumble over one another" is idiomatic but rendered directly.

verses.text: And you shall perish among the nations, and the land of your enemies shall eat you up.
verses.comment: "Eat you up"—land metaphor for being consumed/lost.

verses.text: Those of you who are left will waste away because of their iniquity in your enemies' lands, and also because of the sins of their ancestors, they shall waste away with them.
verses.comment: "Waste away" is literal for Hebrew verb.

verses.text: But if they confess their iniquity and the iniquity of their fathers, with their treachery that they committed against me, and also walk contrary to me,
verses.comment: Confession and repentance as condition for restoration.

verses.text: so that I also walked contrary to them and brought them into the land of their enemies—if then their uncircumcised hearts are humbled and they accept the punishment for their iniquity,
verses.comment: "Uncircumcised hearts" preserved literal Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: then I will remember my covenant with Jacob, my covenant with Isaac, and my covenant with Abraham, and I will remember the land.
verses.comment: Threefold covenant formula kept in order.

verses.text: But the land shall be left deserted by them and shall enjoy its Sabbaths while it lies desolate without them; and they shall accept the punishment for their iniquity, because they rejected my rules and their soul abhorred my statutes.
verses.comment: Summary of exile reason and land's rest.

verses.text: Yet for all that, when they are in the land of their enemies, I will not reject them nor abhor them to destroy them utterly, and to break my covenant with them; for I am the LORD their God.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness emphasized despite judgment.

verses.text: But I will for their sake remember the covenant with their ancestors, whom I brought out of the land of Egypt in the sight of the nations, that I might be their God: I am the LORD.
verses.comment: Restatement of God’s ultimate commitment.

verses.text: These are the statutes and rules and laws that the LORD made between himself and the people of Israel through Moses on Mount Sinai.
verses.comment: Summary verse, ensuring clarity that Moses is mediator.
